pulltitle: fix(db): ensure that requests for bad paths are logged
pullsbody:
@chilts @rfk

Revised from #154, fixes #144, depends on https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-db-mem/pull/39.

Improves on the previous PR in two ways:
1. Uses restify's `NotFound` event to catch all requests to unknown paths.
2. Uses the linked fx-auth-db-mem PR to test that the server emits the failure event as expected.

Any good?
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
fix(db): ensure that requests for bad paths are logged

Fixes #144

pulltitle: fix(db): ensure that requests for bad paths are logged, fixes #144
pullsbody:
I made some assumptions here, so I have questions:
1. I've assumed that whatever is listening for the `'failure'` event is the thing that does the actual logging. Is that correct? Which repo is listening for that event? I tried grepping in a few but didn't find anything.
2. I've not used restify before but couldn't see a better way in the docs to do what I've done in `index.js`. The identical sequential calls to `get()`, `put()`, `post()`, `delete()` and `head()` are a bit smelly, is there any way to wildcard the HTTP verb in restify?
3. There's also an assumption in the general approach I've taken, I'm not sure if it's what you guys had in mind. Obviously I extracted the code in `handleError` to a named function for re-use, but I wasn't sure if that justified extracting the `resolve` handler to a named function too. Doing so would make the async call more uniform and improve readability I reckon, but it's not called from anywhere else so perhaps it's a bit OTT. What do you think?

@chilts @rfk: r?
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message: fix(db): ensure that requests for bad paths are logged, fixes #144

pullsbody:
We're working on a PR to replace JSHint with ESLint in https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-content-server/pull/2578 (and soon in https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-js-client/issues/156).

Not sure if we want to do all the **fxa-auth-**\* servers while we're at it.
One cool thing is that we can use [ESLint shareable configs](http://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/shareable-configs) to check our rules in and easily share them between all the **mozilla/fxa-**\* repos. I have a prototype config at https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-config-fxa.

You can see in the .eslintrc file below where we're extending the "fxa/server" rules defined in **eslint-config-fxa** module and overriding/disabling a couple rules:

``` yaml
extends: fxa/server

rules:
  handle-callback-err: 0
  semi: 0
```

You can see the base ESLint rules in https://github.com/pdehaan/eslint-config-fxa/blob/master/index.js and the "fxa/server" specific rules https://github.com/pdehaan/eslint-config-fxa/blob/master/server.js.

But ESLint is objectively better, more customizable, easier to create custom rules, and updates more frequently. :sparkles:
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message: chore(lint): Replace JSHint with ESLint

pullsbody:
When doing an `npm install` using node v0.12, it complains since grunt-copyright
v0.1 has a `"node": "0.10.x"` in it's `engines` section. v0.2 has been updated
to be `"node": ">= 0.10.0"` which is satisfied with either v0.10 or v0.12.
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
chore(copyright): Update to grunt-copyright v0.2.0

When doing an `npm install` using node v0.12, it complains since grunt-copyright
v0.1 has a `"node": "0.10.x"` in it's `engines` section. v0.2 has been updated
to be `"node": ">= 0.10.0"` which is satisfied with either v0.10 or v0.12.

pulltitle: refactor(tests): Generate test UIDs a different way
pullsbody:
Since we have weird dependency issues related to how the reverse backends work
it may be better off to remove uuid/node-uuid completely so we don't have to
solve it in a weird way. This actually ends up slightly cleaner too, though
we may still have to solve this issue at some point in the future. See
https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-db-mem/issues/23#issuecomment-93856934
for further details.
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
refactor(tests): Generate test UIDs a different way

Since we have weird dependency issues related to how the reverse backends work
it may be better off to remove uuid/node-uuid completely so we don't have to
solve it in a weird way. This actually ends up slightly cleaner too, though
we may still have to solve this issue at some point in the future. See
https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-db-mem/issues/23#issuecomment-93856934
for further details.

pulltitle: refactor(tests): Switch to node-uuid to be consistent with other repos
pullsbody:
Since we had trouble with the uuid@2 package (the uuid.v4() subtly changed
from returning a binary to returning an array) we decided to go back to
node-uuid which we use in other repos. Even this has changed somewhat
so that we just need a slight helper to generate a uuid in a Buffer
a little more easily.
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
refactor(tests): Switch to node-uuid to be consistent with other repos

Since we had trouble with the uuid@2 package (the uuid.v4() subtly changed
from returning a binary to returning an array) we decided to go back to
node-uuid which we use in other repos. Even this has changed somewhat
so that we just need a slight helper to generate a uuid in a Buffer
a little more easily.

pulltitle: I94 fix insert replace account reset tokens
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
Fixes #94 : Make sure we replace rows in specific tables

These include accountResetTokens, passwordChangeTokens and
passwordForgotTokens. All should only have one row per account.

pulltitle: I94 fix insert replace account reset tokens
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
Add tests to make sure certain tokens are replaced

For accountResetTokens, passwordForgotTokens and passwordChangeTokens
we only allow one per accounts.uid and therefore when a 2nd one is
inserted it should be replaced instead of in addition to the first.
These tests make sure that this happens correctly.

pulltitle: I94 fix insert replace account reset tokens
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message:
Failed stored procedures return errors correctly

This test makes sure that if there is an error in a stored procedure
inside a transaction, that the error is propagated back up the stack
and into db/mysql.js. Trying to make an existing SP fail and putting
the correct one back into place seemed a bit fragile, so this adds
a new one (which we know will fail) and then monkey patches `db` so
that it mirrors the other methods by just calling `db.write()`. This
is about as close as we can get without it becoming spaghetti.

pulltitle: pass err.stack so bunyan actually prints more than "uncaughtException"
pullsbody:
I was set up with the wrong value of patchLevel in my config so the server was crashing at startup. Unfortunately, all the error log would say was '"level":60,"op":"uncaughtException","err": {},"msg":"" ...'
which is not the most useful. This change will result in the full stack and root cause ("Error: dbIncorrectPatchLevel") being shown.
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message: pass err.stack so bunyan actually prints more than "uncaughtException"

pullsbody:
Added a few more handy scripts:
- `$ grunt validate-shrinkwrap` — validates an npm-shrinkwrap.json file against https://nodesecurity.io/advisories database.
- `$ npm run outdated` — lists modules in package.json with newer versions.
- `$ npm run shrinkwrap` — lists outdated modules, generates a new npm-shrinkwrap.json file, then validates the shrinkwrap file using `grunt validate-shrinkwrap` task.

``` sh
$ node -v && npm -v
v0.10.30
1.4.21
```

Fixes #62
pull_repo_desc: database layer for Firefox Accounts server
pull_commit_message: Adding grunt validate-shrinkwrap task

Move function to outer scope

Since the 'if' doesn't introduce a new scope, it's best if the function
is at the top level to stop any misunderstandings. This also stops
`grunt jshint` complaining too.

pullsbody:
See GH-33.

This tests the case where it is a sql error and the resulting error has `err.errno == 1146`. 

I need to work out a way to force a socket error to produce the wrapped `err.cause.errno` to have a value.

pulltitle: test: try to create a duplicate account to force duplicate error handling
pullsbody: This will exercise https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-db-server/blob/master/db/mysql.js#L522-531 where it checks the errno. In this case, `err` is not a `RejectionError` as in GH-33, so `err.errno` does equal 1062.
